Boggy.csv.description: qPCR dilution series demonstrating MAK2 model fitting across a range of template concentrations. Six 2-fold dilution points (F1-F6) with duplicate technical replicates showing characteristic exponential amplification and plateau phases.
Boggy.csv.source: Boggy, G.J., & Woolf, P.J. (2010). A Mechanistic Model of PCR for Accurate Quantification of Quantitative PCR Data. PLOS ONE, 5(8), e12355.
characteristics: Demonstrates primer depletion at high concentration
Good for testing model across dynamic range
Boggy.csv.expected_results: Should show decreasing D0 estimates from F1 to F6, with tight confidence intervals and R² > 0.995 for most wells

Rutledge.csv.description: Large-scale qPCR dataset with 6 concentration levels (X1-X6) and 5 experimental replicates (R1-R5), each with 4 technical replicates. **Note:** This data is background-subtracted with many zero values in early cycles. X5-X6 (low template) wells often fail fitting - this is expected and demonstrates MAK2+ behavior on challenging data.
Rutledge.csv.source: Dataset adapted from Rutledge, R.G. qPCR amplification efficiency studies
characteristics: Tests bootstrap convergence at low signal
Some wells will fail - this is expected
Rutledge.csv.expected_results: X1-X3 wells should fit well (R² > 0.99); X4 may have mixed results; X5-X6 expected to have many failures due to very low template and extensive zero baseline

reps.csv.description: Seven concentration levels (F1-F7) with 4 technical replicates each, designed to assess measurement precision and reproducibility across a wide dynamic range. Demonstrates coefficient of variation analysis and quality control metrics.
reps.csv.expected_results: Technical replicates should show CV < 5% for D0 at high concentrations (F1-F4), increasing CV at low concentrations (F6-F7)

usage_notes.data_format: All CSV files with first column 'Cycles' followed by fluorescence columns

citation.software: Boggy, G. (2024). MAK2+: Open-source computational tool for absolute nucleic acid quantification. GitHub. https://github.com/gboggy2/MAK2-plus
citation.original_model: Boggy, G.J., & Woolf, P.J. (2010). A Mechanistic Model of PCR for Accurate Quantification of Quantitative PCR Data. PLOS ONE, 5(8), e12355. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0012355
